I think we can all agree that appliance repair can seem like a daunting task. Additionally, it may be tempting to try and save money by troubleshooting appliance problems ourselves instead of calling a professional for help. Appliance malfunctions can range from small, easily fixable solutions to large, life-threatening issues. Here are five signs that I should call an appliance repairman for help.
1. I See Smoke or Smell Something Burning
Common sense tells us that an appliance emitting smoke is malfunctioning and in need of professional help.  Turning off or unplugging the appliance is not enough and can be a fire hazard in the future. An appliance repairman can help me diagnose the source of the smoke. Additionally, do not hesitate to call 995 in an emergency.
2. My Utility Bills are High
Expensive utility or electricity bills often indicate my appliance(s) may have to put in extra work to get the job done. Dryers with broken heating elements and leaking air conditioners are two common culprits causing my electric bills to skyrocket. 
3. My Appliance is Making a New Sound Repeatedly
Some appliances, such as washing machines and dishwashers can be naturally noisy. However, unexpected grinding or hissing noises can indicate malfunctioning parts of common appliances. Sounds should be investigated immediately to avoid broken parts, massive leaks, and overworked fans or heating/cooling elements.
4. Excess Moisture Builds Up Around my Appliance
Moisture presence promotes mold growth on a wide range of surfaces, including walls, floors, and both inside and outside of appliances. Moisture can pool up near the bottom of leaking appliances, such as washing machines, refrigerators, and A/C units. Additionally, moisture can appear on walls and crevices in humid rooms due to lack of air flow.  If I suspect excess moisture buildup, an appliance repairman can help me diagnose the source of moisture and troubleshoot a plan to dry out.
5. My Appliance is Wobbly or Shifting Unexpectedly
A wobbly appliance is often a sign of being off-balance or a broken part impacting the rotation.  @saladsashimiq @sweety_pie1231 @wafflespiesallthingsnice

💮Answer Portion #2: The ultimate question: Should I Try to Do It Myself?
I am concerned about exposure to the virus and I am tight on funds so I adopted a DIY approach. What I am seeing is that I have real needs, partly caused by the pandemic, partly because things are breaking because we’re at home, and I think I am now realizing I can do a lot more than I might have thought. I am learning to be creative. During the circuit breaker, I watched step-by-step repair tutorial videos, conferred with friends, borrowed tools from a neighbor contactless and did it myself over the course of several weeks. I think it’s good that now I have more of a knowledge of repair work and Circuit Breaker gives me a chance to do that. 
On the other hand, home maintenance falls on a spectrum of difficulty. I do understand that most plumbing and electrical work, for example, is best left to the professionals. One mistake can cause a lot more damage. If I don’t know how to snake a pipe or a garbage disposal, it might leak overnight. In a multi-unit complex, that can get expensive. Because it leaks into the unit below or the unit next door and then it becomes a huge thing. Besides property damage, there’s potential damage I could do to myself, e.g. garbage disposals as one source of danger.
So now that circuit breaker is over and the condition in SG is more stabilized, I will be calling the experts to help with more serious problems.
@missprinqueen @chill_nov_1 @wafflespiesallthingsnice

💮 Answer Portion #1: When I noticed a leak under my bathroom sink in mid-April, I tied it up with an old T-shirt and stuffed junk mail under it. I’d normally call my landlord to take care of it, but government instructions are clear: stay inside and away from others to slow the spread of the coronavirus.
Plumbers, electricians and handymen and -women are considered essential workers during the COVID-19 crisis. They’ve continued to come to the rescue when a pipe bursts or the electricity goes haywire. It’s frequently hazardous work, pandemic notwithstanding.
I am thinking: What’s the sense of me not going out if I have somebody who’s going out to multiple houses coming to my house? That defeats the purpose. Is it life or death, or life and discomfort? If the washing machine won’t wash or the screen door won’t seamlessly slide, does it make sense to call a professional? Does bringing in a worker—or several—put my safety and theirs at risk? Do I try doing it myself? Is fixing a sink as easy as baking bread?
When should I call a professional? If it’s an emergency or serious issue, I will make the call. Some repairs simply can’t be put off. An untreated electrical shortage could spark a fire. A leaky pipe in one apartment could cause thousands of dollars of water damage in the entire complex. In those situations, I consider it’s necessary to bring in a trained professional, ideally before a situation grows dire.
If it’s less urgent, I shall weigh the risks.
If I am with my family of five and my washing machine breaks, it might not be feasible to transition to a washboard. But I don’t want home-repair workers in my unit. On the flip side, some maintenance workers are hesitant to put themselves at unnecessary risk. The latter makes it trickier to find someone to tackle a job immediately and increases the turnaround time for some repairs. It’s not a good time for maintenance unless it’s a serious issue.

Scenario #3: DIY the repairs
You're playing outside with your older sister and she falls off her bicycle. What should you do? (Check to see if she can hear me.)
She answers you but says her knee hurts a little. Her knee is bleeding a little bit. Should you call an ambulance? (No, this isn't a serious injury and she is conscious.)
What should you do? (Go home to clean the injury or go get help from an adult I know.)
For home emergencies that involve objects, at times I can’t always wait for a professional service so I want to try to reduce costs by fixing the problem myself. For some less severe emergencies, DIY repairs are a perfectly valid option provided with such advance technology, I can easily look up for help online via forums, online resources or even online chatbot.  @tristar891 @kenbean3 @movieslover101

1. Assess the risks before calling experts
Determine whether or not it is safe to call experts from where I am. For example, if there is fire in a room or throughout the house, I have to leave the house immediately and then call 995. An unnecessary 995 call could prevent someone who is truly in danger from getting help so I only call when essential.
2. Practice / role-play
Familiarize with possible emergency situations to help reduce panic or anxiety in case of a real emergency.
For example, I create a game with scenarios for my family to test their knowledge. Adapt scenarios accordingly to explore more possible scenarios. Practice several times a year so that we are as prepared as possible to deal with emergencies.
Below are some scenarios I have used before to train my children as they are the ones I worry most in the case of an emergency.
Scenario #1: Call an expert
You're playing in the living room when you hear a loud noise from the kitchen. You go to see what's happening and see mom on the floor. What should you do? (Check to see if mom can hear me.)
Mom answers you, then tries to get up but can't. She is bleeding a lot. Should you call 995? (Yes, I have to call 995 and ask for an ambulance.)
What do you have to tell 995? (The Emergency is at XXX My mom fell down, she can still talk but she's bleeding a lot and can't get up. I am calling from This is also where we live.)
Can you wait for the ambulance with your mom? (Yes. I'm not in any danger.)
Scenario #2 : Call an expert
You come home from school and see that the door to your house is broken, and you think someone you don't know may be inside. What should you do? (Go to my neighbours' house or use a mobile to call 995.)
You come home from school and see that the door to your house is broken, and you think someone you don't know may be inside. What should you tell 995? (Location of the emergency is XXX. Someone I don't know broke down the door to my house and might be inside. I need the police. I am at XXX, my neighbours' house and I'm safe.)
Can you wait for the police? (Yes, but I have to stay at the neighbours', I can't go home to wait for the police).

text:
Usually the most often home emergencies that is happening in my house often concern my aged in-laws. I will always fist recognize if it is a medical emergency situation: 
A medical emergency is a sudden illness that requires immediate medical attention. It is essential for you to recognise a medical emergency situation.
7 signs of a medical emergency that I will look out for are:
Sudden or severe pain, including chest pain
Breathing difficulty or shortness of breath
Uncontrolled bleeding of any kind
Sudden confusion of disorientation
Sudden dizziness, numbness, weakness or vision change
Coughing or vomiting of blood
Continuous vomiting or diarrhoea
I always keep with me a list of all the medicines that my loved one takes, with dosage and special instructions, if any. 
If it is a medical emergency at home, I will call 995 for ambulance.  When I call an ambulance, I will give the age of my care recipient, explain the problem and how long it has been going on. For example: "My 73-year-old mother-in-law has been having difficulty breathing for the past 30 minutes.” I quickly state my oved one’s medical history. For example: “She had a heart attack two years ago.”
I carry my loved one’s personal documents such as identification card and hospital discharge summary in case he/she needs to be admitted. Photocopy important documents (such as current and past medical records and test results) so that I can give emergency personnel this information while keeping the originals.
I always stay calm as much as possible in any home emergency as if I panic, the kids will panic even more. I keep my voice even to stay calmer and also help people around me stay calm. I get my husband to help and never leave my care recipient unattended or move them excessively especially when my in-laws have fallen.
@kenbean3 @movieslover101 @sweety_pie1231

text: Emergencies can happen at any time so no matter what I feel it is important to know how to quickly and efficiently fix the problem. From natural disasters, power loss, appliance failure and no water, emergency repairs tend to be one of the most important repairs for me to be comfortable and confident with. In most cases, I will find the repairs are DIY or fixable with whatever is around the house. Common repairs would be fixing a leak, broken window, flooding, frozen pipes or clogged toilet. Each problem can have a relatively simple fix, a leaky roof and broken window can be patched, flood can be pumped out, pipes can be thawed and repaired and toilets can be unclogged with a chemical. For the most part, emergency repairs are not permanent. They are what I can do fast to stop the problem then have a professional come in to permanently fix it. When I am worrking overseas, flooding as a result of frozen pipes, clogged toilets or a leaky roof can result in very costly water damage repairs and even potential health issues resulting from mold growth if not addressed in a timely manner. Hence I am a DIY first, call expert second type of person. @hasmiley321 @keilymissy @lcyhne

answers.text: @wintersnowy1 An awesome sort of person to be! 💪

text:
It really depends on the complexity of the repair. I follow a general rule of thumb:
1. Gauge the level of skill required for the repair.
2. Search online for videos and instructions for DIY fix. Call up friends for guidance.
3. Decide to DIY or call for experts based on judgement and research information above.
4. DIY if I can manage. If it doesn’t fix the problem, I will call experts.
5. Call up experts straightaway for issues related to electrical and gas appliances and ceiling matter.

If it is a clogged sink, I will first use a plunger. If it does not work, I will use the boiling water method, baking soda and vinegar method to clear the clog. If it fails, I will call the plumber.

For dripping tap, I will cut off the water supply, remove the tap head, wrap plumber's tape to tighten the joint from the inside and seal coupling joints tighter together to prevent further leakage. If dripping still persists, call plumber.

For small, shallow holes or cracks in the walls, I will patch it up with filters myself. If the holes and cracks are long, deep or growing I will call experts immediately as it could meant structural issue with the house.

For replacement of door knob, I will also DIY as it is not too complicated.

Meanwhile, I will sheer clear of any repair work related to holes in ceiling, gas or electrical appliances. Leave it to the experts, as it could be easy to open up the appliances but put them back could be a nightmare. Not to mention the risk of getting hit on the head from crumbs hailed down from the ceiling, injuries or death from gas leakage, electric shock from these appliances due to improper repair work.
FB: Adela Chew @ruyidianxin  @sugarplumteatree @nuitabol

answers.text: @xiaoninger Awesome advice! We learnt something new today 👏

text:
As an avid DIY’er I have done tons of projects and have lots of experience.  Each project is considered a home emergency. The sweat equity has been nice too. Below are some of the projects I have completed over the past four years…
Installed brand new shower in the bathrooms.
Re-finshed all of the kitchen cabinets.
Repainted the entire house.
Re-landscaped and de-weeded overgrown backyards.
Installed closet systems.
Installed new interior doors.
Repainted the front door.
Repaired the gutter.
Installed new light fixtures in the entire house.
Patched large drywall holes.
Fixed a leak in the laundry room.
Sometimes I have had to hire a handyman or specialized vendor aka "EXPERTS" to do the work on our houses. Here are just a few…
Fixed up the entire interior of a foreclosure.
Fireplace inspected and panels replaced.
Molding installed in a bathroom.
Replaced two garage doors.
Installed molding and a closet system.
Repaired the garage disposal.
So the key to determining whether to do my home emergency project DIY or when to call an expert, is to determine what works best for me financially, skill-wise, and time-wise. I have hired out many times simply because I ran out of time and not because I couldn’t do it. The key for me has been to be reasonable on my expectations and price of the materials. Then I make sure that I will still have a significant profit on the cost of the project versus hiring it out. I personally have no desire to do all this work only for me to get as much money back into the house as I put into it. For example: I recently fixed my bathroom and it cost $3,000 for the materials. Even though we had to spend $800 on new tools, the labor was $4,000 for a basic shower. We were able to install a much nicer one. We ended up making over $3,000 in savings. 
@wintersnowy1 @lcyhne @keilymissy

Some people are better at fixing things than others. It’s a fact. And it’s a fact that is not necessarily gender-related.
I found out over the course of my marriage that I, the wife, am generally better at building and fixing things than my husband. If he has to fix something, it often leads to frustration on his part (feels he should be able to, but doesn’t know how) and he gets into a bad mood. I, on the other hand, love to put furniture together, and even like researching how to fix something and then fix it. I have ordered parts online for two washing machines, a dryer, and a dishwasher - and completed the repairs successfully. I figured out how to fix a floor problem downstairs, I remodeled some rooms, even doing demo work, and I’ve painted. I like the sense of accomplishment I get from fixing this stuff. This last week, I fixed the gutters, which had been drooping in a couple of places.
My husband still does some things around the house: he likes pruning the trees and large bushes, and sweeping the walkways, and taking out the garbage, and he likes washing pots and pans.
Figure out which one of you is best at fixing things. If it’s truly neither of you, then look into finding a reliable handyman.
@lcyhne @wintersnowy1 @enxinneverending

I will call the expert = my wife.
I wouldn’t necessarily push. What things does your husband do well? Double-down on those things and appreciate those attributes.
My father was a building code enforcer and master at carpentry. I inherited none of that skill. When my mother would suggest that my father an I spend some time together in the workshop at home you could almost hear the groan from both of us - my father who almost certainly didn’t want me involved and myself who knew I’d be fairly incompetent and a disappointment.
But guess what I did end up good at? Numbers, patterns in numbers, and getting deeply into niche topics like company fundamentals and regulatory compliance. I went to school for economics. I have always been paid well and I am good with “money things” as my wife calls it.
Oh, she certainly makes fun of me, yes. Her father was an engineer and she is good at putting things together, fixing things, etc. I subscribe to what I call the Ricardian household management. I am good at making money doing strategy and analysis. Some other person is good at fixing shit. So, I hire that guy. It’s more efficient. Fortunately for us, it is very clear that I have the financial/business skills.
The moment the washing machine or anything makes a noise, my line is, “I think we need to call the guy”. My wife is like, “let me take a look”. Have fun, just don’t expect me to take a look. It’s a running joke in our house.
@cnyhappy1 @silentxdisco @p1314168

Honestly, there is no definite answer. It has to depend on how confident I am to handle the emergency. And here are just 6 commonly faced emergencies at my house and how I tackle them. ❤️
5. Fixing a Clogged Garbage Disposal
The verdict: Try to DIY it.
A clogged disposal may be cleared by using a small specialty wrench that fits into a hexagonal opening on the underside of the disposal while the disposal is turned off.  I will call a professional if this method doesn’t clear the stoppage.
6 Replacing a Door
The verdict: Hire a pro.
While a new door can help brighten up a space and cut down on heating and cooling costs, these savings are best spent on making sure the installation job is done right. Any major door overhaul should be handled by a professional. For example, turning my two windows into an opening for beautiful French or sliding glass doors

@cnyhappy1 @jacksonivyp @p1314168 1
Fixing a Leaky Kitchen or Bathroom Pipe
The verdict: Try to DIY it.
A DIY fix for a drain pipe may be simply tightening a slip-nut near the P-Trap. If the leak is directly from a hole in the drain pipe, a DIY fix would be a flexible coupling with hose clamps. If the leak is from a drain pipe inside the wall, I will consider calling a professional.
2
Hanging Wallpaper
The verdict: Hire a pro.
The challenge with hanging wallpaper is getting it straight on the wall and matching up the patterns correctly. It typically requires two people to do the job. Sometimes bubbling can happen, which means a strip of paper will need to be removed and a new strip reinstalled. This can result in not having enough wallpaper and needing to order more. While only I can decide whether the DIY savings outweigh potential risks, hiring a professional guarantees a smooth and predictable outcome.
3
Painting the Exterior of My Home
The verdict: Hire a pro.
Painting the exterior of a house is a big job. Most homes require all of the trim, soffits, and rake boards and, depending on the type of home, all of the siding as well. This requires extensive use of ladders at high levels and sometimes climbing up on the roof. I will need to consider safety requirements before tackling an exterior job. 
4
Removing Popcorn Ceilings
The verdict: Hire a pro.
Removing popcorn ceilings is gaining in popularity lately, but is an extremely messy job. First, the popcorn must be sprayed and softened by a softening agent. Then, all of the surface area must be scraped with a blade. While scraping, it is impossible not to create divots and holes on the surface. Those divots and holes need repair with compound that will need to dry and then be sanded smooth. Finally, everything needs to be primed and then painted with two coats of paint. The work is overhead and requires ladders. For a job like this, I will hire a professional and save myself the headache and probably less-than-desired results.

Below are some of the home emergencies I have experienced personally:
1. During a power outage, the safest course is to disconnect all appliances and electronics. That way, I’ll avoid damage from power surges when the juice returns to my home. I take great care using candles for illumination, exercising proper fire safety, and be sure to stock up on batteries and flashlights 
2.  Getting locked out of the house is a little embarrassing, and,that time I had to call a locksmith, which was mightily expensive. 😱  Keeping a hidden key poses security risks. So I now remove my extra key from inside the hide-a-key garden stone or from under the back porch door mat, and consider leaving it with my trusted friend or neighbor instead.
3. Kitchen fire is the most scary one I have experienced!  First, I don’t panic. I keep a box of baking soda in a handy spot for dousing flare-ups in a toaster or stovetop pan. I also avoid tossing water on the blaze, and don’t try to smother the flames with a dishtowel or anything that could catch fire. The better course of action is to use a pot lid to extinguish the flames. If it’s an oven fire, I don’t open the door—close the oven and the fire should extinguish itself. Although some fire extinguishers are rated to extinguish grease fires, those handheld fire fighters can spread flames rather than extinguish them when used improperly. As such, I went to those free RC courses and educate myself on the types of extinguishers and how to use them so I am always ready in case of a disaster.
@p1314168 @jacksonivyp @silentxdisco

text:
@silentxdisco @jacksonivyp @cnyhappy1 It depends on the difficulty level of the emergency.
Level 1: Clogged Sink + Leaky Faucet
Forget calling a plumber—I can totally fix minor sink problems on my own. Even better? I probably have the tools needed—such as a plunger, wrench, and screwdriver—at home already.
Scratched & Creaky Floorboards
No matter how lightly I tread, there will be unexpected wear and tear on my floorboards. But I don't need to call an expert to fix it for me.
Level 2: 
Electrical issues. Problems like breaker trips, electrical buzzing and humming, and flickering lights when the system kicks on are all signs of a electrical issues. These can be really dangerous, so I will be calling an emergency furnace service if after restarting the electrical system or changing the light bulbs the problems still exist. 
Level 3:
Gas odors in the home. A gas leak is never something to fiddle around with. If I smell gas from my gas system, I will definitely be calling an emergency team right away.

answers.text: @p1314168 Awesome gameplan! 👏
@graywzy_ Some things are best left to the pros! 👍

text:
Steps to take when an emergency occurs:
Take a deep breath.
Count to 10. Tell myself I can handle the situation. I can repair the person. I can DIY.
Check for danger. Protect myself and the injured person from fire, explosions, or other hazards.
Try to look at the situation as a whole.
What is the most serious problem and what do I need to do first? The most obvious problem is not always the most serious.
Treat the most life-threatening problems like bleeding or shock first.
If I think the person has a spinal injury, I do not repair or move him or her unless the danger is great.
Check for broken bones and other injuries.
If the person is unconscious or does not respond to my voice or touch, I will be ready to start repairing her via CPR. I will call the correct emergency services, such as the local fire department, sheriff, or hospital, if I need help from experts. @lcyhne @keilymissy @hasmiley321

Call an expert. Tackling a DIY job gives you a certain amount of satisfaction and saves you money too. Some jobs, however, should be left to the professionals.
There are jobs around the home that can easily be undertaken by DIY enthusiasts, often saving the homeowner money in the process. However, there are jobs that should always be left to the professionals, mainly because things could turn nasty if and when something goes wrong.
Unfortunately, many of those who regularly undertake maintenance on their homes don’t know their own limitations and repairs done outside their scope of expertise may not only end up costing a lot more to fix, things can become downright dangerous if the job isn’t done correctly.
